item.description: Sometimes one is unable to find a single argument that works in general to prove a statement. Consider the statement

item.title: 2.1.3. Working backwards
item.description: In this example, given a positive real number $x$, we wish to determine whether one of the expressions $\frac{x}{x+1}$ and $\frac{x+1}{x+2}$ is always larger than the other.

item.title: 2.1.4. Proving biconditional statements
item.description: So far we have not proved any bicondition, or “iff” statements. Let’s try to prove the familiar statement that for all real numbers $a,b$ with $b \ge 0$, $$ \boxed{|a| \leq b \text{ iff } -b \leq a \leq b} $$ First, we must remember that there are two statements to proved, the forward ($\implies$) direction $$ \text{if } |a| \leq b, \text{ then } -b\leq a\leq b, $$ and the backwards ($\impliedby$) direction $$ \text{if }-b\leq a\leq b, \text{ then }|a|\leq b.

item.title: 2.1.5. Uniqueness proofs
item.description: Sometimes we find that not only do we wish to prove that an object exists, hut also we wish to prove that the object that exists is unique.

item.title: 2.2.1. Proof by contradiction
item.description: In Subsection 1.2.2. and [[notes/Mathematics/TTOMR/2.1 More Direct Proofs|2.1 More Direct Proofs]], we have been concentrating on direct proofs of statements such as $p\implies Q$, $(\forall x)P(x)$, and $(\exists x)P(x)$.

item.title: 2.2.2. Proving the contrapositive
item.description: To motivate our second method of indirect proof, we will show that $$ \boxed{\text{for all } n\in\mathbb{Z} \text{, if } n^2 \text{ if odd, then } n \text{ is odd}} $$ It’s easy to see why we should try to use an indirect proof.

item.title: Basic Properties of Integers 1.2.3
item.description: For all integers a, b, c Property Definition Closure under + and $\cdot$ $a + b$ and $ab$ are also integers Associative properties $(a + b) + c = a + (b+c)$ and $(ab)c = a(bc)$ Commutative properties $a + b = b + a$ and $ab = ba$ Distributive properties $a(b+c)=ab+ac$ Identities $0 \ne 1$, $a+0=a$, $a \cdot 1 = a$, and $a \cdot 0 = 0$ Additive inverses There is a unique integer $-a=-1 \cdot a$ such that $a + (-a) =0$ Subtraction $b-a$ is defined equal to $b + (-a)$ No divisors of 0 If $ab = 0$, then $a = 0$ or $b = 0$ Cancellation If $ab = ac$ and $a \ne 0$, then $b = c$ Transitive property of < If $a < b$ and $b < c$, then $a < c$ Trichotomy Exactly one of $a < b$ or $a = b$ or $a > b$ holds Order property 1 If $a < b$ , then $a + c < b + c$ Order property 2 If $c > 0$ , then $a < b$ iff $ac < bc$ Order property 3 If $c < 0$ , then $a < b$ iff $ac > bc$ Note in particular the cancellation property of integers; there is no division operation in the integers.

item.title: Basic Properties of Real Numbers 2.1.4
item.description:
For real integers a, b, c Property Definition Closure under + and $\cdot$ $a + b$ and $ab$ are also integers Associative properties $(a + b) + c = a + (b+c)$ and $(ab)c = a(bc)$ Commutative properties $a + b = b + a$ and $ab = ba$ Distributive properties $a(b+c)=ab+ac$ Identities $0 
e 1$, $a+0=a$, $a \cdot 1 = a$, and $a \cdot 0 = 0$ Additive inverses There is a unique integer $-a=-1 \cdot a$ such that $a + (-a) =0$ Subtraction $b-a$ is defined equal to $b + (-a)$ Multiplicative inverses If $a 
e 0$, then there is a unique real number $a^{-1} =  rac{1}{a}$ such that $a \cdot a^{-1} = a \cdot  rac{1}{a} = 1$ Division When $a 
e 0$, $ rac{b}{a}$ is defined equal to $b \cdot  rac{1}{a}$ Transitive property of < If $a < b$ and $b < c$, then $a < c$ Trichotomy Exactly one of $a < b$ or $a = b$ or $a > b$ holds Order property 1 If $a < b$ , then $a + c < b + c$ Order property 2 If $c > 0$ , then $a < b$ iff $ac < bc$ Order property 3 If $c < 0$ , then $a < b$ iff $ac > bc$ There is one additional axiom for $\mathbb{R}$, called the Completeness Axiom.

item.title: Definition 1.2.1.
item.description: Let $n \in \mathbb{Z}$ $n$ is $even$ if there exists an integer $k$ such that $n = 2k$; i.e., $$ n \text{ is } even \text{ if } (\exists k \in \mathbb{Z})[n = 2k] $$ $n$ is $odd$ if there exists integer $k$ such that $n = 2k + 1$; i.

item.title: Definition 2.1.1
item.description: Let $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$ $$ a \text{ divides } b \text{ if there exists } n \in \mathbb{Z} \text{ such that } b =an $$ We write $a | b$ for “$a$ divides $b$” and say that $a$ is a divisor of $b$

item.title: Definition 2.1.11.
item.description: Given $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the absolute value of $x$, denoted by $|x|$, is defined by $$ |x| = \begin{cases} x & \text{if } x \geq 0,\ -x & \text{if } x < 0 \ \end{cases} $$

item.title: Definition 2.1.7.
item.description: A positive integer $p$ is $prime$ if $p > 1$ and the only positive integer factors of $p$ are 1 and $p$; i.

item.title: Definition 2.3.2.
item.description: The positive integer $p$ is prime if $$ p>1 \text{ and }(\forall m,n\in\mathbb{Z}^{+})[p=mn\implies(m=1 \lor n=1)] $$

item.description: Let $A$ and $B$ be sets. Then $A$ is a subset of $B$ (in notation, $A \subseteq$ B) if every element of $A$ is also an element of $B$.

item.title: Exercises 2.4
item.description: Determine whether each statement is true or false, and prove or disprove, as appropriate. a) $(\forall x\in\mathbb{R})(\exists y\in\mathbb{R})[xy=1]$ b) $(\exists x\in\mathbb{R})(\forall y\in\mathbb{R})[xy=1]$ c) $(\exists x\in\mathbb{R})(\forall y\in\mathbb{R})[xy>0]$ d) $(\forall x\in\mathbb{R})(\exists y\in\mathbb{R})[xy>0]$ e) $(\forall x\in\mathbb{R})(\exists y\in\mathbb{R})(\forall z\in\mathbb{R})[xy=xz]$ f) $(\exists y\in\mathbb{R})(\forall x\in\mathbb{R})(\exists z\in\mathbb{R})[xy=xz]$ g) $(\forall x\in\mathbb{Q})(\exists y\in\mathbb{Z})[xy\in\mathbb{Z}]$ h) $(\exists x\in\mathbb{Z}^{+})(\forall y\in\mathbb{Z}^{+})[y\leq x]$ i) $(\forall y\in\mathbb{Z}^{+})(\exists x\in\mathbb{Z}^{+})[y\leq x]$ j) $(\forall x,y\in\mathbb{Z})[x<y\implies(\exists z\in\mathbb{Z})[x<z<y]]$ k) $(\forall x,y \in\mathbb{Q})[x<y\implies(\exists z\in\mathbb{Q})[x<z<y]]$ Prove that $\lim_{ x \to -\frac{1}{2} }(4x-1)=-3$ Let $f(x)=\begin{cases}\ 5-2x & \text{if } x \ne 4,\\ 23 & \text{if } x =4 \\end{cases}$ Prove that $\lim_{ x \to 4 }f(x)=-3$ Prove that there exists a real number $M$ such that for all $x\in\mathbb{R}$ with $1<x<3$, $|\frac{5x^2-2x-4}{5(x^2+1)}|\leq M$ Assume that for every real number $x$, there is an integer $N$ such that $N>x^3$ (this follows from Archimedean Property proved in Chapter 9).

item.title: Exercises 3.1
item.description: All exercises should be proved using induction Prove that for all positive integers $n$, $\sum_{k=1}^{n}k^2=1^2+2^2+3^2+\dots+n^2=\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}$ Prove that for all integers $n\geq 0$, $\sum_{k=0}^{n}2^k=1+2+2^2+\dots+2^n=2^{n+1}-1$ Prove that for al positive integers $n$, $\sum_{k=1}^{n}(2k-1)=1+3+5+\dots+(2n-1)=n^2$ Prove that for all positive integers $n$, $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{k(k+1)}=\frac{1}{1(2)}+\frac{1}{2(3)}+\frac{1}{3(4)}+\dots+\frac{1}{n(n+1)}=\frac{n}{n+1}$ Prove that for all positive integers $n$, $\sum_{k=1}^{n}(2k-1)^2=(1)^2+(3)^2+(5)^2+\dots+(2n-1)^2=\frac{4n^3-n}{3}$ Conjecture a formula for $\sum_{k=1}^{n}(-1)^kk^2$, and then prove the formula is correct using induction Prove that for all positive integers $n,n<10^n$ Prove that for all positive integers $n\geq 5,n^2<2^n$ Prove that for all positive integers $n\geq 7,(\frac{4}{3})^n>n$ Prove that for all positive integers $n\geq 4,2^n<n!

item.title: Exercises 3.2
item.description: Let $a_{1}=2,a_{2}=4,$ and $a_{n+1}=7a_{n}-10a_{n-1}$ for all $n\geq 2$. Conjecture a closed formula for $a_{n}$ and then prove your result. Let $a_{1}=3,a_{2}=4,$ and $a_{n+1}=\frac{1}{3}(2a_{n}+a_{n-1})$ for all $n\geq 2$.

item.title: Notation 3.1.2.
item.description: Suppose that $i\leq n$ are integers and $a_{i},a_{i}+1,\dots,a_{n}$ are real numbers. Then $$ \sum_{k=i}^{n}a_{k}=a_{i}+a_{i+1}+\dots+a_{n} $$

item.title: Notation 4.1.1.
item.description: Given a set $A$, we write $x\in{A}$ for “$x$ is an element of the set $A$”, and we write $x\notin A$ for “$x$ is not an element of the set $A$”.

item.title: Notation 4.1.2.
item.description: Let $P(x)$ be a statement with a single free variable $x$. Then the notation $$ {x \mid P(x)} \quad \text{ or } \quad {x:P(x)} $$ denotes the set of all objects $x$ in the underlying universal set such that $P(x)$ is true.

item.title: Problem #45
item.description: [[notes/Project Euler/Project Euler MOC|Project Euler MOC]] Problem Triangle, pentagonal, and hexagonal numbers are generated by the following formulae: Triangle $T_{n}=n(n+1)/2$ $1,3,6,10,15,…$ Pentagonal $P_{n}=n(3n−1)/2$ $1,5,12,22,35,…$ Hexagonal $H_n=n(2n−1)$ $1,6,15,28,45,…$ It can be verified that $T_{285}=P_{165}=H_{143}=40755$.

item.title: Proof of Proposition 2.2.5.
item.description: [[notes/Mathematics/TTOMR/Proposition 2.2.5.|Proposition 2.2.5.]] Let $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$ be arbitrary with $b\geq 0$, and assume that $a^2\geq b$. We prove that $a\geq \sqrt{ b }$ or $a\leq-\sqrt{ b }$ (note that $\sqrt{ b }$ makes sense since $b\geq 0$).

item.title: Proposition 1.1.15
item.description: P ⇒ Q is logically equivalent to (¬Q) ⇒ (¬P ) P ⇒ Q is not logically equivalent to Q ⇒ P

item.title: Proposition 2.1.10
item.description: For all positive real numbers $x, \frac{x}{x+1} < \frac{x+1}{x+2}$. Proof. Let $x \in \mathbb{R}$ be arbitrary with $x > 0$. We must show that $$ \frac{x}{x+1} < \frac{x+1}{x+2} $$ First note that by an order property, $$ x^2+2x <(x^2+2x)+1 $$ and hence, by factoring $$ x(x+2) <(x+1)^2 $$ Since $x>0$, we know that $(x+1)(x+2)>0$, and hence we may divide both sides of the statement by $(x+1)(x+2)$ to obtain $$ \frac{x(x+2)}{(x+1)(x+2)}<\frac{(x+2)^2}{(x+1)(x+2)} $$ by another order property.

item.title: Proposition 2.1.12
item.description: For all real numbers $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$ with $b\geq 0$, $|a|\leq b$ if and only if $-b\leq a\leq b$. Proof.

item.title: Proposition 2.1.3
item.description: For all integers, a, b, c if a | b and b | c, then a | c Proof. Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{Z}$ be arbitrary and assume that $a | b$ and $b | c$.

item.title: Proposition 2.1.6
item.description: For all $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$ with $a < b < 0$, $a^{2} > b^{2}$ Proof. Let $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$ with $a < b < 0$.

item.title: Proposition 2.1.9
item.description: For all integers $a, a(a+1)$ is even Proof. Let $a \in \mathbb{Z}$. We show that $a(a+1)$ is even by considering two cases.

item.title: Proposition 2.2.1
item.description: There do not exist integers $m$ and $n$ such that $12m+9n=100$. Proof. Assume for the sake of a contradiction that we have integers $m$ and $n$ such that $12m+9n=100$.

item.title: Proposition 2.2.2
item.description: For all real numbers $x$ and $y$, if $x$ is rational and $y$ is irrational, then $x+y$ is irrational. Proof. Let $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$ be arbitrary, and assume that $x$ is rational and $y$ is irrational.

item.title: Proposition 2.2.3
item.description: For all $n\in\mathbb{Z}$, if $n^2$ is odd, then $n$ is odd Proof. Let $n\in\mathbb{Z}$ be arbitrary. We prove the contrapositive. Assume that $n$ is even; we show that $n^2$ is also even.

item.title: Proposition 2.2.4
item.description: For all $n\in\mathbb{Z}$ if $n^2$ is even, then $n$ is even Proof. This is [[notes/Mathematics/TTOMR/Exercises 2.2|Exercises 2.2]] #1.

item.title: Proposition 2.2.5
item.description: For all real numbers $a$ and $b$ with $b\geq 0$, if $a^2\geq b$, then $a\geq \sqrt{ b }$ or $q\leq-\sqrt{ b }$

item.title: Proposition 3.1.3
item.description: For all $n\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}$, $$ \sum_{k=1}^{n}k=\frac{n(n+1)}{2} $$ Proof. Given $n\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}$, let $P(n)$ denote the statement $$ \sum_{k=1}^{n}k=\frac{n(n+1)}{2} $$ We prove $(\forall n\in\mathbb{Z}^{+})P(n)$ by induction on $n$

item.title: Proposition 3.1.5
item.description: For all integers $n\geq 10,n^3\leq 2^n$ Proof. Let $n\in\mathbb{Z}$ with $n\geq 10$, and let $P(n)$ denote the statement $$ n^3\leq 2^n $$ We prove by induction on $n$ that for all integers $n\geq 10, P(n)$ is true

item.title: Prove Something is a Widget

item.title: Theorem 2.1.5.
item.description: $\text{Let } n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$ Assume $n$ is even. Then every $x \in \mathbb{R}$ with $x \ge 0$ has a real “$n$th root”; i.

item.title: Theorem 2.3.1.
item.description: $\sqrt{ 2 }$ is irrational Proof. Assume for the sake of a contradiction that $\sqrt{ 2 }$ is rational. By definition, we may fix $p,q\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}$ such that $\frac{p}{q}=\sqrt{ 2 }$, and by removing common factors if necessary, we may also assume that $p$ and $q$ do not have any common positive integer factors other than 1.

item.title: Theorem 2.3.3 (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic)
item.description: Every positive integer greater than $1$ can be written as a product of primes. Furthermore, this product of primes is unique, except for the order in which the factors appear.

item.title: Theorem 2.3.4
item.description: (Euclid). There are infinitely many prime numbers. Proof. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that there do not exist infinitely many prime numbers, i.

item.title: Theorem 3.1.1. (Principle of Mathematical Induction (PMI))
item.description: Updated Definition in [[notes/Mathematics/TTOMR/Theorem 3.1.4. (Principle of Mathematical Induction (modified))|Theorem 3.1.4. (Principle of Mathematical Induction (modified))]] Let $P(n)$ be a statement about the positive integer $n$, so that $n$ is a free variable in $P(n)$.

item.title: Theorem 3.1.4. (Principle of Mathematical Induction (modified))
item.description: Let $P(n)$ be a statement about the integer $n$, where $n$ is free in $P(n)$ Suppose that there is an integer $n_{0}$ such that: (PMI 1) The statement $P(n_{0})$ is true (PMI 2) For all integers $m\geq n_{0}$ $$ \text{if } P(m) \text{ is true, then } P(m+1) \text{ is true} $$ Then, for all integers $n\geq n_{0}, P(n)$ is true

item.title: Theorem 3.2.1 (Principle of Strong Mathematical Induction (PSMI)
item.description: Let $P(n)$ be a statement about the positive integer $n$ Suppose the following: (PSMI 1) The statement $P(1)$ is true (PSMI 2) For all positive integers $m$ $$ \tag{3.
